title: StructuredPy: Master Python through Objects and Functions
text:
Introduction
Welcome to StructuredPy, a practical guide to building well-structured Python applications. This book takes a hands-on approach to learning Python through real-world projects, focusing on both functional and object-oriented programming approaches.

title: StructuredPy: Master Python through Objects and Functions
text:
Who This Book Is For
This book is designed for:

Python beginners who understand basic syntax and want to write better code
Programmers transitioning to Python from other languages
Anyone interested in building practical Python applications

title: StructuredPy: Master Python through Objects and Functions
text:
What You‚Äôll Build
Throughout this book, you‚Äôll work on three main projects:

Time Series Data Analysis

Analyze sensor data using both functions and classes
Learn data processing techniques
Visualize time series data

Device Communication

Build a mock serial communication system
Handle device commands and responses
Manage device state and errors

API Development

Create a FastAPI server
Connect devices through web APIs
Build a complete application


Each project is presented twice: first using functions, then using classes. This approach helps you understand when to use each style and how to combine them effectively.

title: StructuredPy: Master Python through Objects and Functions
text:
How to Use This Book

Project-Based Learning
Each chapter focuses on building something practical. We start with a problem, break it down into manageable pieces, and build a solution step by step.


Code Examples
All code examples are available in the code directory. For each project, you‚Äôll find:
code/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ timeseries/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ device/
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ api/


Exercises and Practice
Each chapter includes: - Hands-on exercises - Code challenges - Suggestions for extending the projects

title: StructuredPy: Master Python through Objects and Functions
text:
Prerequisites
To get the most out of this book, you should:

Know basic Python syntax (variables, loops, conditionals)
Have Python installed on your computer
Be comfortable using a text editor or IDE
Have a basic understanding of the command line

If you need to review Python basics, check the appendix for a quick reference.

title: StructuredPy: Master Python through Objects and Functions
text:
Getting Started

Clone the book‚Äôs repository:
git clone https://github.com/Ameyanagi/StructuredPy
Install the required packages:
pip install -r requirements.txt
Start with Chapter 1 and follow along with the code examples.

title: StructuredPy: Master Python through Objects and Functions
text:
What Makes This Book Different
Instead of teaching Python concepts in isolation, this book:

Shows both functional and object-oriented approaches
Uses real-world examples
Focuses on writing maintainable code
Demonstrates practical project organization

title: StructuredPy: Master Python through Objects and Functions
text:
Navigation

Use the sidebar to navigate between chapters
Code examples can be copied directly from the book
Projects build on each other progressively

Let‚Äôs begin by analyzing time series data in Chapter 1!

title: StructuredPy: Master Python through Objects and Functions
text:
Acknowledgments
Thanks to all contributors and reviewers who helped improve this book.

title: StructuredPy: Master Python through Objects and Functions
text:
Contributing
Found a mistake or want to improve the book? Visit the GitHub repository to:

Report issues
Suggest improvements
Contribute content

title: Preface
text:
Why This Book Exists
Python‚Äôs flexibility is both a blessing and a curse. While it allows you to solve problems in many ways, it can be challenging to know which approach is best. This book aims to bridge the gap between writing code that just works and writing code that‚Äôs clear, maintainable, and scalable.

title: Preface
text:
Our Approach
We believe in learning by doing. Instead of abstract concepts, we focus on practical projects that you might encounter in real work. Each project is implemented twice:

First using functions - Simple, straightforward, and easy to understand
Then using classes - Organized, maintainable, and scalable

This dual approach helps you understand: - When to use each style - The trade-offs involved - How to combine approaches effectively

title: Preface
text:
Book Structure
Each project follows this pattern:

Problem Introduction

What we‚Äôre building
Why it matters
Expected outcomes

Functional Solution

Step-by-step implementation
Key concepts explained
Code organization

Object-Oriented Solution

Converting to classes
Benefits and trade-offs
Design decisions

Practical Extensions

Real-world considerations
Common challenges
Further improvements

title: Preface
text:
Key Principles
Throughout the book, we emphasize:

Writing clear, focused code
Building maintainable solutions
Making conscious design decisions
Testing and error handling
Real-world applications

title: Preface
text:
A Note on Style
There‚Äôs rarely one ‚Äúright‚Äù way to solve a programming problem. We present approaches that are:

Clear to understand
Easy to maintain
Practical to implement
Well-tested in real applications

title: Preface
text:
Getting Help
If you get stuck:

Check the code in the book‚Äôs repository
Review the chapter‚Äôs key concepts
Try breaking the problem into smaller pieces
Check the online resources in the appendix

Remember: Every experienced programmer was once a beginner. Take your time, practice with the examples, and don‚Äôt hesitate to experiment with the code.
Let‚Äôs start building better Python applications!

title: 1¬† Initial Setting and Tutorial
text:
1.1 Prerequisites
This tutorial will guide you through setting up a modern Python development environment with best practices for:
By following this guide, you‚Äôll create a well-structured Python project that follows some of the best practices that people use for python. The setup includes automatic testing, documentation generation, and code quality checks - essential tools for professional Python development.
Before starting this tutorial, you should have:
But if you don‚Äôt have any of these, don‚Äôt worry! You can refer to the Appendix for more information.

title: 1¬† Initial Setting and Tutorial
text:
Basic Python knowledge
A GitHub account
A text editor or IDE of your choice
Terminal/command line familiarity

title: 1¬† Initial Setting and Tutorial
text:
1.2 Setting up Git

1.2.1 Initial Setup

1.2.1.1 Installing Git
Before you can use Git, you need to install it on your system:

Windows: Download and install from git-scm.com
macOS: Install via Homebrew: brew install git
Linux: Install via package manager:
# Ubuntu/Debian
sudo apt-get install git

# Fedora
sudo dnf install git




1.2.2 Configuring Git
After installation, configure your identity: This will be required when you are pushing the code to the GitHub.
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "you@example.com"
Additional recommended configurations: Whenever you are pushing to the GitHub, you will be asked for the username and password. To avoid this, you can store the credentials securely. If you are not using GitHub, then you can skip this step.
# Store credentials securely
git config --global credential.helper store

title: 1¬† Initial Setting and Tutorial
text:
1.3 GitHub Setup (Optional)
GitHub is a popular platform for hosting Git repositories and collaborating on code. You can use it to store your code, track changes, and work with others on projects. You can also use GitHub Actions for continuous integration and deployment (CI/CD) workflows.
You will need to create an account on GitHub and set up a personal access token to push code to GitHub.

1.3.1 Creating a GitHub Account

Go to github.com and sign up for an account
Verify your email address
Set up two-factor authentication (recommended)



1.3.2 Creating a Personal Access Token
Modern GitHub security requires using tokens instead of passwords:

Go to GitHub Settings ‚Üí Developer settings ‚Üí Personal access tokens ‚Üí Tokens (classic)
Click ‚ÄúGenerate new token (classic)‚Äù
Select scopes:

repo (Full control of private repositories)
workflow (if using GitHub Actions)
read:org (if working with organization repositories)

Set an expiration date
Generate and copy the token immediately (it won‚Äôt be shown again)

Store your token securely - you‚Äôll need it when pushing to GitHub.

title: 1¬† Initial Setting and Tutorial
text:
1.4 uv: Modern Python Package Management
uv is a new-generation Python package installer and resolver written in Rust. It offers several advantages over traditional tools like pip:

Extremely fast package installation and dependency resolution
Built-in virtual environment management
Compatible with pip‚Äôs interface and package formats
Reliable dependency resolution
Optimized for modern Python development

Here, we will only be focusing on the installation and minimal validation of the uv that is required for the project.
If you want to know more about uv, you can visit the official website here

1.4.1 Installation

1.4.1.1 Installation Methods

Unix/macOS
curl -LsSf https://astral.sh/uv/install.sh | sh
Windows (PowerShell)
powershell -ExecutionPolicy ByPass -c "irm https://astral.sh/uv/install.ps1 | iex"







Note



Note: After installation on Windows, you may need to add uv to your PATH. The installation location is %USERPROFILE%\.local\bin. You can add this to your PATH by:

Press Windows + X and select ‚ÄúSystem‚Äù
Click ‚ÄúAdvanced system settings‚Äù
Click ‚ÄúEnvironment Variables‚Äù
Under ‚ÄúUser variables‚Äù, find and select ‚ÄúPath‚Äù
Click ‚ÄúEdit‚Äù
Click ‚ÄúNew‚Äù
Add %USERPROFILE%\.local\bin
Click ‚ÄúOK‚Äù on all windows






1.4.2 Verifying Installation
You can verify the installation by opening a new terminal or PowerShell window and running:
uv --version

title: 1¬† Initial Setting and Tutorial
text:
1.5 Summary
In this tutorial, you learned how to set up a modern Python development environment with Git, GitHub, and uv. These tools will help you manage your code, collaborate with others, and install Python packages efficiently.
In the next chapter, we‚Äôll create a new Python project using a cookiecutter template and set up a basic project structure.

title: 2¬† Project Initialization Guide
text:
2.1 Understanding Project Structure
We will be using boilerplate that includes modern dependency management with uv, comprehensive testing setup with pytest, documentation with MkDocs, code quality tools, CI/CD with GitHub Actions, Docker support, and dev container configuration for VSCode. This will give you a solid foundation for professional Python development without having to set up each component manually.
Before we dive into creating a new project, it‚Äôs important to understand what makes up a well-structured Python project:

title: 2¬† Project Initialization Guide
text:
Source code directory (your main package)
Tests directory
Documentation
Build configuration files
Development tools configuration
CI/CD configuration
License and README files

title: 2¬† Project Initialization Guide
text:
2.2 Using Cookiecutter

2.2.1 What is Cookiecutter?
Cookiecutter is a project template tool that we‚Äôll use through uvx to create our project structure. It uses a templating engine to replace project variables with your custom values, ensuring consistent project structure across all your repositories.


2.2.2 Project Template Selection
We‚Äôll use the cookiecutter-uv template created by Florian Maas, which is specifically designed for modern Python projects using uv. This well-maintained template includes:

Modern dependency management with uv
Comprehensive testing setup with pytest
Documentation with MkDocs
Code quality tools (ruff, mypy)
CI/CD with GitHub Actions
Docker support
Dev container configuration for VSCode



2.2.3 Project Initialization Workflow
Here‚Äôs a high-level overview of the project initialization workflow: The green boxes represent automated steps, while the red boxes represent manual steps.





graph TB
    Init[Project Initialization] --> Cookie[Run Cookiecutter]
    Cookie --> Setup[Setup Project Structure]
    Setup --> Git[Initialize Git]
    Git --> Install[make install]
    
    Install --> DevLoop[Development Loop]
    
    subgraph DevLoop[Development Loop]
        direction TB
        WriteTest[Write Test] --> Test1[make test]
        Test1 --> Code[Write/Edit Code]
        Code --> Test2[make test]
        
        Test2 -->|Fail| Code
        Test2 -->|Pass| Check[make check]
        
        Check --> Docs[make docs]
        Docs --> CommitGroup
        
        subgraph CommitGroup[Git Commit Process]
            direction LR
            Commit[Git Commit]
            PreCommit[Pre-commit Hooks:<br/>- Check Conflicts<br/>- Ruff Format<br/>- Ruff Lint<br/>- Prettier]
        end
        
        CommitGroup --> CI[GitHub Actions CI]
        CI --> Deploy[make publish]
    end
    
    %% Manual steps
    classDef manual fill:#f9d6d6,stroke:#d64545
    class Code,Commit,Init,Cookie,WriteTest,Git manual
    
    %% Automated steps
    classDef automated fill:#d4edda,stroke:#28a745
    class Install,Check,Test1,Test2,Docs,Deploy,CI,PreCommit automated
    
    %% Subgraphs
    classDef process fill:#e6f3ff,stroke:#0056b3
    class CommitGroup process
    
    %% Container
    style DevLoop fill:#f0f0f0,stroke:#333,stroke-width:2px








2.2.4 Creating Your Project
Run the template generator:
uvx cookiecutter https://github.com/fpgmaas/cookiecutter-uv.git
Once you run the command, you will be prompted to enter some information about your project. This information will be used to generate the project structure and files.
Installed 22 packages in 11ms
  [1/14] author (Florian Maas): Ameyanagi
  [2/14] email (fpgmaas@gmail.com): contact@ameyanagi.com
  [3/14] author_github_handle (fpgmaas): Ameyanagi
  [4/14] project_name (example-project): StructuredPy-code
  [5/14] project_slug (structuredpy_code):
  [6/14] project_description (This is a template repository for Python projects that use uv for their dependency management.): This is a repository containing the example project used in the StructuredPy
  [7/14] Select include_github_actions
    1 - y
    2 - n
    Choose from [1/2] (1):
  [8/14] Select publish_to_pypi
    1 - y
    2 - n
    Choose from [1/2] (1):
  [9/14] Select deptry
    1 - y
    2 - n
    Choose from [1/2] (1):
  [10/14] Select mkdocs
    1 - y
    2 - n
    Choose from [1/2] (1):
  [11/14] Select codecov
    1 - y
    2 - n
    Choose from [1/2] (1):
  [12/14] Select dockerfile
    1 - y
    2 - n
    Choose from [1/2] (1):
  [13/14] Select devcontainer
    1 - y
    2 - n
    Choose from [1/2] (1):
  [14/14] Select open_source_license
    1 - MIT license
    2 - BSD license
    3 - ISC license
    4 - Apache Software License 2.0
    5 - GNU General Public License v3
    6 - Not open source
    Choose from [1/2/3/4/5/6] (1):


2.2.5 Project directory
You can check the initial directory tree by running the following command:
tree -a -L 4 StructuredPy-code # Please change the directory name to your project name or a directory name you specified in the cookiecutter command
The output will be like this:
StructuredPy-code
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ codecov.yaml
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ CONTRIBUTING.md
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .devcontainer
‚îÇ¬†¬† ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ devcontainer.json
‚îÇ¬†¬† ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ postCreateCommand.sh
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Dockerfile
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ docs
‚îÇ¬†¬† ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.md
‚îÇ¬†¬† ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ modules.md
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .editorconfig
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .github
‚îÇ¬†¬† ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ actions
‚îÇ¬†¬† ‚îÇ¬†¬† ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ setup-python-env
‚îÇ¬†¬† ‚îÇ¬†¬†     ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ action.yml
‚îÇ¬†¬† ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ workflows
‚îÇ¬†¬†     ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ main.yml
‚îÇ¬†¬†     ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ on-release-main.yml
‚îÇ¬†¬†     ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ validate-codecov-config.yml
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .gitignore

‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tests
‚îÇ¬†¬† ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ test_foo.py
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ tox.ini

9 directories, 23 files


2.2.6 Initializing git repository
git init
git add .
git commit -m "first commit"
git branch -M main
git remote add origin https://github.com/Ameyanagi/StructuredPy-code.git
git push -u origin main


2.2.7 Installing the python dependencies
make install
This will run the following command:
uv sync
uv run pre-commit install
The output will be like this:
üöÄ Creating virtual environment using uv
Using CPython 3.13.1 interpreter at: /usr/bin/python3

title: 2¬† Project Initialization Guide
text:
2.3 Summary
In this chapter, you learned how to initialize a new Python project using the cookiecutter-uv template. This template provides a modern Python project structure with uv, pytest, MkDocs, and other tools to help you get started quickly.
In the next chapter, we‚Äôll explore how to write and run tests for your Python project using the project structure we just created.

title: 3¬† General workflow of coding
text:
3.1 Open code in Editor
This guide will walk you through creating and maintaining a Python project, from writing code to testing, documentation, and version control. You‚Äôll learn how to write testable code following Test Driven Development (TDD) principles, create clear documentation, and manage your codebase with Git.
Open the root directory of the project in your preferred code editor (VSCode, Neovim, etc.).

title: 3¬† General workflow of coding
text:
3.2 Running the code
The source code is included in the structuredpy_code directory. By default the foo.py file is included in the directory. You can run the code by running the following command:
uv run structuredpy_code/foo.py
At this moment, there will be no output, because the foo.py file is empty.
def foo(bar: str) -> str:
    """Summary line.

    Extended description of function.

    Args:
        bar: Description of input argument.

    Returns:
        Description of return value
    """

    return bar


if __name__ == "__main__":  # pragma: no cover
    pass
We will be make a new file and work on that file, but configuration would be the same.

title: 3¬† General workflow of coding
section: 3.3 Creating a python file and running it
text:
3.3 Creating a python file and running it
Let‚Äôs create a new file called hello.py in the structuredpy_code directory. In the hello.py file, we will write a simple function that prints ‚Äúhello world‚Äù to the console.
def main():
    print("hello world")


if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
You can run the code by running the following command:
uv run structuredpy_code/hello.py
The output will be like this:
hello world

title: 3¬† General workflow of coding
text:
3.4 Test the code
Let‚Äôs look at the test file in the tests directory. The test file is called test_foo.py and it tests the foo function in the foo.py file.
from structuredpy_code.foo import foo


def test_foo():
    assert foo("foo") == "foo"

3.4.1 Running the test
You can run the test by running the following command:
make test
This command will run the following command:
uv run python -m pytest --cov --cov-config=pyproject.toml --cov-report=xml
The output will be like this:
üöÄ Testing code: Running pytest
=================================================================== test session starts ===================================================================
platform linux -- Python 3.13.1, pytest-8.3.4, pluggy-1.5.0
rootdir: /home/ameyanagi/StructuredPy-code
configfile: pyproject.toml
testpaths: tests
plugins: cov-6.0.0
collected 1 item

tests/test_foo.py .                                                                                                                                 [100%]

---------- coverage: platform linux, python 3.13.1-final-0 -----------
Coverage XML written to file coverage.xml


==================================================================== 1 passed in 0.03s ====================================================================
What this does is that it runs the test file cnd see if the code runs with out the error. In the test_foo.py file, we are testing the foo function in the foo.py file will return the same string that we passed to it. assert is a keyword that is used to check if the condition is true. If the condition is false, it will raise an AssertionError.

3.4.1.1 Basics of Test Driven Development (TDD)
TDD is a software development process that relies on the repetition of a very short development cycle: requirements are turned into very specific test cases, then the software is improved so that the tests pass. The cycle is repeated until the software is complete.
Let‚Äôs assume we want to add a new function called add in the foo.py file. We will first create a add function stub in the test_foo.py file.
def add(a, b):
    pass
Then in the test_foo.py file, we will write a test for the add function. Here, we will write 4 tests for the add function to check if the function works as expected.
from structuredpy_code.foo import add

def test_add():
    assert add(1, 2) == 3

def test_add_negative():
    assert add(-1, -2) == -3

def test_add_zero():
    assert add(0, 0) == 0

def test_add_float():
    assert add(1.5, 2.5) == 4.0
Then we will run the test by running the following command:
make test
We now see that all the tests have failed, because we have not implemented the add function yet. The main idea of TDD is to write the test first, then implement the function to make the test pass.
Let‚Äôs implement the add function in the foo.py file to make the test pass.
def add(a, b):
    return a + b
Then run the test again by running the following command:
make test

title: 3¬† General workflow of coding
text:
3.5 Documentation

3.5.1 Writing Good Documentation

3.5.1.1 Module-Level Documentation
Every Python module should start with a docstring explaining its purpose:
"""
Data processing module for time series analysis.

This module provides functions for loading, processing, and analyzing
time series data with a focus on financial applications.

Classes:
    TimeSeriesData: Container for time series with metadata
    DataProcessor: Handles data cleaning and transformation

Functions:
    load_data: Load time series from various file formats
    process_data: Clean and preprocess time series data
"""


3.5.1.2 Writing Effective Docstrings
Docstrings serve two key purposes: 1. In-code documentation for developers 2. Source for automated documentation tools
Documentation generators like MkDocs and Sphinx can parse docstrings to create: - API reference documentation - Function/class indexes - Example galleries - Module hierarchies
For best results with these tools: 1. Follow Google Style Guide conventions 2. Include all parameters and return types 3. Add examples for complex functions 4. Document exceptions and edge cases
Example of a well-documented function:
def process_data(data: np.ndarray, window_size: int = 5) -> np.ndarray:
    """Process time series data using rolling window calculations.

    Args:
        data: Input time series array of shape (n_samples,)
        window_size: Size of rolling window for calculations

    Returns:
        Processed data array of shape (n_samples - window_size + 1,)

    Raises:
        ValueError: If window_size is larger than data length
        TypeError: If data is not a numpy array

    Examples:
        >>> data = np.array([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])
        >>> process_data(data, window_size=3)
        array([2., 3., 4.])
    """



3.5.2 Generating API Documentation
MkDocs with Material theme provides excellent API documentation:
make docs
This will run the following command:
uv run mkdocs serve
The output will be like this:
make docs
INFO    -  Building documentation...
INFO    -  Cleaning site directory
INFO    -  Documentation built in 0.25 seconds
INFO    -  [02:42:02] Watching paths for changes: 'docs', 'mkdocs.yml'
INFO    -  [02:42:02] Serving on http://127.0.0.1:8000/StructuredPy-code/
In this case, the documentation will be available at http://127.0.0.1:8000/StructuredPy-code/ in your web browser. You can quickly see that the documentation of the foo function is available in module section of the documentation, but the add function is not available in the documentation. This is because the add function does not have a docstring.
The docstring is a string that is used to document the code. It is written in the first line of the function, class, or module. There are several formats for writing docstrings, but we will be using the Google style for writing docstrings.
Let‚Äôs add a docstring to the add function in the foo.py file.
def add(a, b):
    """Add two numbers.

    Args:
        a: The first number.
        b: The second number.

    Returns:
        The sum of the two numbers.
    """
    return a + b
Then run the test again by running the following command:
make docs
You can check from the docs that the add function is now available in the documentation. We have to note that the type definition is not available in the documentation, because we have not added the type definition to the function. Let‚Äôs add the type definition to the add function in the foo.py file.
def add(a: number, b: int) -> int:
    """Add two numbers.

    Args:
        a: The first number.
        b: The second number.

    Returns:
        The sum of the two numbers.
    """
    return a + b
Now we can see that the type definition is now available in the documentation. The type definition is not necessary for the code to run, but it is a good practice to add the type definition to the function in terms of readability and maintainability of the code.

title: 3¬† General workflow of coding
text:
3.6 Commit the code to Git
You can commit the code to Git by running the following command:
git add .
git commit -m "add add function"
Then if you want to push the code to GitHub, you can run the following command:
git push

title: 3¬† General workflow of coding
text:
3.7 Summary
In this chapter, we have learned how to create a new file, write a simple function, test the function, write documentation, and commit the code to Git. This is the basic workflow of coding that you will follow throughout the project.

title: 4¬† Python Basics
text:
4.1 Variables and Data Types
This appendix covers the fundamental Python concepts you‚Äôll need for this tutorial.

title: 4¬† Python Basics
text:
4.1.1 Basic Data Types
# Numbers
temperature = 25.5       # Float
count = 10              # Integer

# Strings
message = "Hello"       # String
device_id = 'DEV001'    # String (single or double quotes)

# Booleans
is_connected = True     # Boolean
is_ready = False       # Boolean

# None (null value)
result = None          # None type


4.1.2 Lists and Dictionaries
# Lists (ordered, changeable)
temperatures = [25.5, 26.0, 25.8]
devices = ['DEV001', 'DEV002', 'DEV003']

# Accessing list elements
first_temp = temperatures[0]     # 25.5
last_device = devices[-1]        # 'DEV003'

# Changing list elements
temperatures[0] = 26.5

# Adding to lists
temperatures.append(26.2)

# Dictionaries (key-value pairs)
device_info = {
    'id': 'DEV001',
    'temperature': 25.5,
    'connected': True
}

# Accessing dictionary values
device_id = device_info['id']           # 'DEV001'
temp = device_info.get('temperature')   # 25.5

title: 4¬† Python Basics
4¬† Python Basics
4¬† Python Basics
4¬† Python Basics
text:
4.5 String Formatting
# f-strings (recommended)
temp = 25.5
message = f"Temperature: {temp}¬∞C"

# Format method
message = "Temperature: {:.1f}¬∞C".format(temp)

# String concatenation
message = "Temperature: " + str(temp) + "¬∞C"

title: 4¬† Python Basics
text:
4.6 File Operations
# Reading files
with open('data.txt', 'r') as file:
    content = file.read()        # Read entire file
    lines = file.readlines()     # Read lines into list

# Writing files
with open('log.txt', 'w') as file:
    file.write("Temperature log\n")
    file.write(f"Reading: {temp}\n")

# Appending to files
with open('log.txt', 'a') as file:
    file.write(f"New reading: {temp}\n")

title: 4¬† Python Basics
text:
4.7 Modules and Imports
# Importing entire modules
import time
time.sleep(1)

# Importing specific items
from datetime import datetime
current_time = datetime.now()

# Importing with alias
import pandas as pd
df = pd.DataFrame()

title: 4¬† Python Basics
text:
4.8 Essential Built-in Functions
# len() - Length of sequences
length = len([1, 2, 3])     # 3

# range() - Number sequences
for i in range(5):          # 0 to 4

# print() - Output
print(f"Value: {value}")    # Formatted output

# type() - Get type of object
data_type = type(value)     # Get type

# str(), int(), float() - Type conversion
text = str(123)             # Convert to string
number = int("123")         # Convert to integer
decimal = float("12.3")     # Convert to float

title: 4¬† Python Basics
text:
4.9 List Operations
# Common list methods
values = [1, 2, 3]
values.append(4)            # Add to end
values.insert(0, 0)         # Insert at position
values.remove(2)            # Remove value
values.pop()               # Remove and return last item

# List slicing
first_two = values[0:2]     # Get first two items
reversed_list = values[::-1]  # Reverse list

# List comprehension
squares = [x**2 for x in range(5)]

title: 4¬† Python Basics
text:
4.10 Dictionary Operations
# Common dictionary methods
info = {'id': 'DEV001'}
info['temp'] = 25.5        # Add/update key-value
value = info.get('id')     # Safe get with default
info.update({'connected': True})  # Update multiple

# Checking keys
if 'id' in info:
    print("Has ID")

# Dictionary comprehension
squares = {x: x**2 for x in range(3)}

title: 4¬† Python Basics
section: 4.11 Common Modules Used in This Tutorial
text:
4.11 Common Modules Used in This Tutorial
# Time and dates
import time
time.sleep(1)              # Wait 1 second

from datetime import datetime
now = datetime.now()       # Current time

# JSON handling
import json
data = json.loads('{"temp": 25.5}')  # Parse JSON
text = json.dumps(data)    # Convert to JSON

# System operations
import os
path = os.path.join('folder', 'file.txt')

title: 4¬† Python Basics
text:
4.12 Code Style Guidelines

Use clear, descriptive names
Use snake_case for functions and variables
Add spaces around operators
Use 4 spaces for indentation
Add comments for complex logic
Keep functions focused and small
Handle errors appropriately

Example of well-styled code:
def calculate_average_temperature(readings):
    """Calculate average temperature from a list of readings."""
    if not readings:
        return None
        
    try:
        total = sum(readings)
        return total / len(readings)
    except Exception as e:
        print(f"Error calculating average: {e}")
        return None

title: 4¬† Python Basics
text:
4.13 What‚Äôs Next
This appendix covered the Python basics needed for our tutorial. As you work through the main chapters, refer back here if you need to review any concepts.
